title: 108_s780
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chief Martin Congressional Gold Medal Act". Chief Phillip Martin has provided exceptional leadership to the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians for over 45 years, leading them to preserve their social and cultural identity while achieving prosperity. His vision and determination have resulted in economic growth, the establishment of a new government, and the revival of the tribe. Chief Martin's efforts have focused on creating a strong tribal economy to provide jobs, dignity, and improve the quality of life for the Choctaw people. Under Chief Martin's leadership, the Choctaw tribe has transformed from poverty to prosperity, becoming major employers in Mississippi with thousands of jobs created. Martin's belief in self-reliance has driven ambitious developments on the reservation despite opposition from Federal authorities. Chief Martin led the Choctaw tribe to establish a tribally-owned construction company and an industrial park, creating manufacturing jobs on the reservation. He also formed partnerships with the private sector, leading to a solid economic foundation for the tribe. Additionally, he took over the operation of the tribe's education system from the Bureau of Indian Affairs, recognizing the value of the community's people. The Choctaw tribe operates a large tribal school system with multiple schools. Chief Martin established the Choctaw Indian Scholarships Program to support education for tribal members. The Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act of 1975 promoted self-reliance and tribal initiative for American Indian peoples. Chief Martin's dedication to tribal sovereignty, trust land, and economic development has transformed the impoverished Choctaw reservation into a successful community, earning him recognition as one of the greatest American Indian leaders. Chief Phillip Martin, an outstanding example of Indian Country's greatest leaders, deserves recognition and honor from the United States Congress. Chief Phillip Martin will be presented with a Congressional Gold Medal in recognition of his leadership of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians for over 45 years and his contributions to the American Indian community. The gold medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to cover costs for medals struck under this Act. Sales of duplicate bronze medals will deposit funds into the same Fund.
